question.title: Impact of high CPU usage on a background thread execution in Java
question.body:
Context

There are many ways of creating a "background thread" in Java. I want to spin off exactly one thread that keeps running in the background. I'm using ScheduledExecutorService for this.

I want that thread to run at a fixed interval of 2 seconds (between consecutive executions). This thread makes a network call to a service with a total timeout of 1 second.

As I understand, specifying a priority to a thread is an OS dependent behavior and is merely a suggestion to the OS to prioritize that thread over other threads in the system.

Question

  1. What is the guarantee that my thread will continue executing at a regular interval (at least once every 3 seconds) despite the CPU usage shooting up (say >= 70%) ?

  2. Is there a way of guaranteeing this? Is this a platform dependent question? Removing this to make this Q more focused on the essentials.

Update: Clarification

Some details about the background thread's characteristics:

  1. The majority of the thread's time will be spent in performing a blocking REST API call using JAX-RS with JerseyClient's implementation.
  2. The remaining time is spent in doing cheap processing work that involves processing a JSON response of < 1 KB and updating an in-memory HashMap.
  3. This thread will be running in a Web app processing requests in an AWS ECS cluster (auto-scaling enabled) - and we wouldn't want the CPU to go beyond 70%. It will only shoot up beyond 70% due to an unexpected spike which is extremely rare.
  4. If the thread gets delayed beyond 3 seconds once in ~1000 times (works 99.9% times), it should be okay. So I don't need it to be real-time (100%).

Also, when I mentioned 70% CPU, I meant 70% of the overall compute capacity available to the application (including cores etc).
